wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Wizzie Wizzie is a London based Saturday morning computer coding club for 8-14 year olds who want to learn how to make their own games and other cool stuff using computer code.
Coding is what makes games, websites and applications possible. The apps on your phone and the games on your console are all made with code.
Do I need to be a boffin…
No way! You just need basic computer skills and the ability to read. If you know how to use a mouse and keyboard then you’ve already got what it takes..
What is a Wizzie Wizzie club like?
Take a look at some of our clubs.

We offer free coding classes for 8-14 year-olds. The 90 minute classes are held on Saturdays during which the children are taught Scratch, Ruby, Python and HTML/CSS.
All the tutors are proferssional programmers and are DBS checked. We currently run four clubs and are planning to expand soon.
Please fill in the form with your details to sign-up now.

TEACH CODING

Diverse Digital is an educational technology charity. It aims to help equip young  people with the technology skills they need for the future. Through the Wizzie Wizzie Computer Coding Club, Diverse Digital aims to teach young people how to code and the problem-solving skills they need for the future.

THE CLUB INTRODUCES YOUNG PEOPLE TO:

  • Scratch
  • Ruby
  • Python
  • HTML/CSS

Information For Volunteering

We’re looking for enthusiastic individuals who are confident coders to share their skills and learning with young people. When Required: Saturday mornings or afternoons. Types Of Activity:
  • Teaching children different types of computer languages
  • Teaching problem-solving skills
  • Supporting children with developing their ideas
  • Contributing to planning of coding sessions
  • Training other volunteers on different learning tools and programming languages
Skills & Qualifications: Confidence with one or more of the following:
  • Scratch, Ruby, Python, HTML/CSS
Expenses: Refreshments provided Training: Core training on the different tools used

item.title: Some Quote
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: The primary school curriculum is changing, computing hardware and programming environments are being created to make it easy to get started with programming and young people seem excited to be part of it all.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "Nothing is more satisfying than helping the children create. I am constantly surprised by the kind of things they come up with"
North Library Manor Gardens London N7 6JX
Rochelle School Arnold Circus London E2 7ES
Nelson's Row (behind the Methodist Church), 121 Clapham High Street London SW4 7JR

item.title: Laptops Donated by Krome Technologies Ltd.
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: In February we received 20 refurbished laptops from Sam Mager, Director of Krome Technologies Ltd. Krome is a major UK technology consultancy whose primary business is helping businesses achieve their business goals with the application of pertinent technology solutions. The donated machines allowed us to launch a branch of our club at the Queen Mother Moore School in Clapham.

item.title: Third Club launched at Rochelle School
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Our third club was launched at Rochelle School last autumn, thanks to the generous support of Director Hatty Buchanan and Studio Manager Mike Carney. In early Spring, Rochelle commissioned noted videographer Alejandro Negueruela to make a short promotional of the work of the club at Rochelle. Thanks to Hatty Buchanan for her generosity and Alex Pascal for supplying the music for the video.
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OjJ4JoIOUhg" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Queen Mother Moore School Club Launched
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Spring saw the launch of our fourth club in Clapham. The venue is the Queen Mother Moore School (QMMS) , located in the premises of the Clapham Methodist Church on the High Street.
QMMS is a supplementary school founded by Rev Hewie Andrew in the early 1980s. The presence of the club is due to his persistence and enthusiasm for learning.

item.title: Club Resuming & Updated Session Times
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
The Wizzie Wizzie Computer Coding Club will be resuming for the Summer session this Saturday 18th of July.
Summer Session: Begins: 18 July Ends: 29 August
Class times: North Library - 11.30am to 1.00pm West Library - 11.00am to 1.30pm Rochelle School - 2.00pm to 3.30pm Queen Mother Moore School - 11.00am to 12.30pm

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: "Wizzie Wizzie is an great initiative that helps kids understand the basics of programming, if something like this was around when I was a child I think would've given me a practical foundation in programming and would've help me progress at a faster rate. From what I've noticed teaching the kids, I have no doubt that some of them will have a brilliant career in the tech industry."

item.title: Glide - a new game maker was released this week
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Glide lets you write games with awesome graphics using real programming languages. It’s not the coloured blocks of Scratch, this is REAL programming. Though you can write a game in just a few lines of code, there are no limits to what you can create.  We’ve given you some samples to show you how to do stuff, and some simple games to inspire you. So please, give it a go! Let us know what you think.  We’re adding new features all the time and we want them to be the features you want.

Languages Supported:

  • Groovy
  • Ruby
  • Javascript
Coming Soon:
  • Python
  • Java
Downloads:
  • Linux 32 bit
  • Linux 64 bit
  • Windows
  • Mac

item.title: Wizzie Wizzie at Festival of Code 2015
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded: Members of the Shoreditch Wizzie Wizzie Computer Coding Club attended the week-long Festival of Code 2015 organised by Young Rewired State this summer. After four days of developing a coding project with the help of Digital Eagles, Barclays, Canary Wharf, the members went to Birmingham to enter the nationwide final. Children aged from 8-18 presented their projects to judges, who then decided on the winners. Members of our Club reached the semi-final with the project, ALlama - an alarm clock linked to live traffic and train information so it could 'go off' earlier or later depending on travel conditions. The overall winners included projects to help make cycling safer and to help car drivers stop filling-up with the wrong sort of petrol.

item.title: Downloads
item.dc:creator: spencer
item.content:encoded:
Club rules

Club Rules

Glide - A development environment for kids

Glide lets you write games with awesome graphics using real programming languages. It’s not the coloured blocks of Scratch, this is REAL programming. Though you can write a game in just a few lines of code, there are no limits to what you can create.  We’ve given you some games you can hack, or you can write your own thing. So please, give it a go! Let us know what you think.  We’re adding new features all the time and we want them to be the features you want.  

Languages Supported:

  • Groovy
  • Ruby
  • Javascript
  • Python
Downloads:
  • Linux 32 bit
  • Linux 64 bit

item.title: Session Schedules for the Autumn.
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Next Saturday (29th of August) will be the last week for the Summer session. We're taking a short break to recruit more members and tutors and will be resuming for the Autumn session on Saturday 19th of September.
End of Summer Session: Saturday 29 August Start of Autumn Session: Saturday 19 September
As always, if you have any questions - please get in contact.

item.title: Student Spotlight: Jeremiah (age 9)
item.dc:creator: david

item.title: About Us
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
The Wizzie Wizzie Computer Coding Club (W2C3) is a project of Diverse Digital, an education technology charity. The project offers free computer coding classes to 8-14 year-olds. The 90-minute classes are held on Saturdays during which the children are taught Scratch, Ruby, Python and Groovy. All our tutors are professional programmers and are CRB checked. We currently run four clubs in London. Our mid-term aim is to have a Club in every London Borough. The project is entirely self-financing. The W2C3 was founded in 2013 by tech journalist and former City University journalism lecturer Milverton Wallace and computer programmer Dave Sutherland. Our Trustees are:
  • Professor Gus John, educationalist and activist, honorary fellow at the Institute of Education, University of London and Chair of the Communities Empowerment Network - http://www.gusjohn.com/
  • Nick Lockett, commercial and IP lawyer, CEO at ADL Solicitors
  • Professor Dave Nicholas, former head, Department of Information Science, City University, and director, Department of Information Studies, University College London. Now director of CIBER Research Ltd
  • David Sutherland, computer programmer​ ​[david@wizziewizzie.org]
  • Atiti Sosimi, games developer
  • Milverton Wallace, tech journalist [milverton@wizziewizzie.org]

item.title: Krome Technologies Support Wizzie Wizzie Computer Coding Club with big donation of computers
item.dc:creator: david
item.content:encoded:
Krome Technologies has agreed to supply us with 120 laptops in 2016. They'll deliver them as and when we need them throughout the year. Pls see their press release here.

We’re delighted that Krome Technologies has taken a leadership role in helping to prepare our children and young people to face and embrace the digital future. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="616"] Krome supports children’s coding charity with the donation of laptops to enable their 2016 expansion plans.[/caption] Read more on the Krome site
